problem.markdown:
>>Over the entire range of possible arrival rates, how does 1 M/M/s queue of \(s* \mu\) total capacity compare to s M/M/1 queues each of \(\mu\) capacity?<< ( ) 1 M/M/s queue of \(s* \mu\) is always significantly faster than s M/M/1 queues of \(\mu\) capacity. (x) 1 M/M/s queue of \(s* \mu\) is sometimes significantly faster than s M/M/1 queues of \(\mu\) capacity. ( ) 1 M/M/s queue of \(s* \mu\) is equally fast as s M/M/1 queues of \(\mu\) capacity. ( ) 1 M/M/s queue of \(s* \mu\) is always significantly slower than s M/M/1 queues of \(\mu\) capacity.
[explanation] When the arrival rate approaches the capacity of the system, \(s* \mu\), there is no idle time in any server, and the lag time of both systems are approximately the same. When the arrival rate is significantly less than \(s* \mu\) however, there will be times when one or some queues in the multiple queue system that are empty and thus are not fully utilized. This leads to a slower performance and longer lag times. [explanation]

This leads to a slower performance and longer lag times.
